text: [music playing]
JOSE URBACH: I am Jose Urbach.
I am 77 years old.
I was born in Poland.

MAGDA ROSENBERG: My
name is Magda Rosenberg.
I'm 88 years old.

All of my family perished
in the Holocaust,
and I'm the only survivor.

SAMI STEIGMANN: My
name is Sami Steigmann.
I'm 77 years old.

And I was born in Czernowitz,
which at that time
belonged to Romania.
Today it's in Ukraine.

HANAN SIMHON: When the survivors
came to the United States,

they had so much
trauma in their lives

that it was difficult for
them to formally find jobs.

And so they did what
they could to survive.
They're very resilient.

But at the same time, they
weren't necessarily able to pay

into a system that
would provide them

with long range, long
term care benefits
later on as they became seniors.

SAMI STEIGMANN: I was with
my parents in a labor camp.

The German government
admits that they

did medical
experiments in Ukraine
and that I was one of them.

I'm still in chronic
pain every single day.

MAGDA ROSENBERG: Whenever
I start talking about it,

I start to cry
and I can't do it.

HANAN SIMHON: Whereas many
seniors have family to rely on

to support them and to help them
in life as they become older,

all the survivors' families
were murdered during the war.

And whereas many seniors
have assets and inheritance

that they procured
over their lifetime,

the survivors of
the Holocaust had
all of that stolen from them.

MAGDA ROSENBERG: I am not
making too much money,

but I have to work to
supplement my income.

JOSE URBACH: My father
was killed in Buchenwald.

We were in the
concentration camp

and they took most of
the men the night before.

The next day we were
liberated, my mother and I.

From 9/11 on,
everything changed.
I lost my job.

The money, little by
little, started to vanish.

We didn't have any
other source of income.
There are lots of limitations.

We have to be careful with
the food we buy, everything.

SAMI STEIGMANN: I got involved
with the wrong people.
I lost everything.
And I was in a shelter.
I was there for six months.

And I finally got the
housing where I live today.

As long as I can, I
will remain independent.

But I do know since I'm by
myself, there is nobody else,
I have no family.

I do know that at some
point I may need help.

HANAN SIMHON: There
are many survivors
that are still alive today.

And so we want to
get to a situation

where we're able
to help them now
and not read about them later.
Now is the time.
We can't wait till next year.

MAGDA ROSENBERG:
We're dying out!

In another 10 years, there
won't be another Holocaust
survivor left.
